Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Theoretical study of the removal of triplet Herzberg states of oxygen by collisions with nitrogen
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor George McBane and his students at Grand Valley State University will conduct calculations that will seek to describe the energy transfer reaction of electronically excited oxygen molecules (O2) with nitrogen (N2). The goal of the research is to identify the major pathways of the reaction, determine the relative importance of each, estimate their rates, and determine how the excess energy is deposited in the products. Diabatic potential energy surfaces will be constructed using ab initio techniques and the atomic motion on those surfaces will be modeled with trajectory surface hopping calculations. A series of studies at restricted geometries will be used to guide the final computational approach, since a brute-force computational attack on the problem is too expensive to be practical.

The results of this research will be useful both to atmospheric modelers and to experimentalists seeking new information on excited states of oxygen in the atmosphere. The work will be carried out by Professor McBane and undergraduate students at Grand Valley State, and collaborator Dr. Reinhard Schinke of the Max Planck Institute for Dynamics and Self Organization in Germany, who brings expertise in electronic structure calculations. The research will strengthen the role of computational research in the student community at GVSU, improve the computational infrastructure there, and bring modern theoretical tools to bear on an outstanding problem in aeronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electronically excited oxygen molecules (O2 in the "triplet Herzberg states'') are formed high in the atmosphere by several mechanisms, and act as a reservoir of solar energy.  This energy ultimately becomes distributed in the atmosphere as heat.  The initial steps in the distribution mechanism are largely unknown, though it is known that the first step for the majority of the excited molecules involves collision with nitrogen [1].  This project used computational methods to study collisions between the Herzberg-state oxygen molecules and nitrogen. Computational models of collisions with neon, a simpler one-atom collider with some properties similar to nitrogen, were also constructed. Four undergraduate students and one high school teacher participated in the work.


Laboratory studies from several different groups have provided clues about the relaxation process.

  • When isolated ozone (O3) molecules are dissociated with ultraviolet light at 226 nm, a few of the product oxygen molecules are formed in the  triplet Herzberg states [2]. 
  • When ozone is photodissociated in a bath of excess N2, ground state oxygen molecules with very large vibrational excitation are present with stable concentrations after two microseconds [3].
  • Oxygen molecules in the triplet Herzberg states with vibrational  excitation lose that vibrational energy very inefficiently in collisions [1].
  • Oxygen molecules can switch efficiently betwen one triplet Herzberg state and another in collisions [1].

The experimenters who measured the highly vibrationally excited O2 arising from ozone photodissociation in a nitrogen bath interpreted it as an immediate product of the dissociation reaction,and the nitrogen as playing no important role in its formation [3].  However, later theoretical study could find no apparent means of production of O2 with that much vibrational energy directly from the photodissociation, though a means of producing O2 in the triplet Herzberg states was apparent.  The theoretical work inspired the more recent experiment that showed that the triplet Herzberg states were definitely formed as a minor product of the dissociation [2].

 
These results suggested that the vibrationally excited O2 from ozone photodissociation in an N2 bath had come from a two-step process: first, dissociation to produce O2 in the triplet Herzberg states, and then conversion of the triplet Herzberg states to ground state, vibrationally excited, oxygen molecules by collisions with nitrogen. If that hypothesis was correct, then this same process would also play an important role in the atmospheric process that removes the triplet Herzberg states.  The current study was designed to model collisions between oxygen in the triplet Herzberg states and nitrogen, and if possible identify and characterize the conversion process.

The computational study confirmed and explained two characteristics of the collisions named above.  First, it is relatively easy for the excited molecules to switch from one triplet Herzberg state to another during collisions.  Second, vibrational excitation in those electronic states is not removed quickly during collisions; a typical molecule would require hundreds of collisions to lose one quantum of vibrational energy. The study identified the pathways by which both of those processes occur, and showed that they should be present for collisions with either nitrogen or neon.
